snippet: It’s impossible to assert that marriage equality is a prudent wager for a presidential candidate in 2012.
abstract: Frank Bruni Op-Ed column expresses measured sympathy for Pres Obama, who faces a dilemma concerning the endorsement of marriage equality during a contentious election year; contends that a full-throated endorsement could cause political damage for Obama in battleground states. (M)
lead_paragraph: Just two days after his inimitably voluble vice president kind of, sort of, probably came out in favor of same-sex marriage, and just a day after his education secretary expressed more succinct, unambiguous support for it, Barack Obama is scheduled to visit New York and cross paths with the governor who is arguably the Democratic standard-bearer for marriage equality, Andrew Cuomo. And it will be clearer than ever: on this issue, the president isn't leading. He's following. And the gap by which he trails others in his party grows broader and sadder.
